section: Except as agreed upon by mutual consent, the Joint Venturers shall not be required to make any capital contribution to the Joint Venture.
explanation: This section states that capital contributions are not required unless mutually agreed upon. However, the document later discusses division of income and losses (Section 6) and distributions (Section 9), implying that there are contributions to have income from. The lack of clarity around how income is generated if there is no initial required capital contribution creates a contradiction.

section: On any termination of the Joint Venture, its debt shall be paid or provided for in a manner deemed reasonable by a third-party mediator, regardless of the satisfaction of the Joint Venturers. Then, any unexpended portion of Joint Venture funds shall be distributed to the Joint Venturers in accordance with their prorata ownership in the Joint Venture, but all other assets of the Joint Venture shall be distributed based on the discretion of the third-party mediator, irrespective of the parties' prorata interests.
explanation: This section outlines the procedure for termination and liquidation. It states that unexpended funds are distributed according to prorata ownership (Section 6), but other assets are distributed at the discretion of a third-party mediator, irrespective of prorata interests. This creates a contradiction, as it establishes two different methods for distributing assets upon termination, and does not make it clear which assets are to be considered “unexpended funds” versus “other assets”.

section: The Joint Venture shall commence on the 1st of March, 2003, and shall be effective until February 28, 2004 unless extended by either joint venturer providing notice of extension. Such extension shall be valid for one year.
explanation: The agreement specifies that either joint venturer can extend the agreement. However, it does not specify how much notice is required before the expiration date of February 28, 2004. A lack of clarity on the notification period needed introduces ambiguity and potentially disputes over whether the extension was validly executed.
